unnormalised: **Automotive News: Fuel Efficiency Gains Momentum, but Challenges Remain**
normalised: **Automotive News: Fuel Efficiency Gains Momentum, but Challenges Remain**

unnormalised: New Delhi: India's automotive sector is witnessing a renewed focus on fuel efficiency, driven by rising petrol prices and growing environmental concerns. Dr. Anjali Sharma, head of Automotive Research at IIT Madras, highlighted recent advancements in engine technology and lightweight materials contributing to improvements of up to 15% in fuel economy across various car models.
normalised: New Delhi: India's automotive sector is witnessing a renewed focus on fuel efficiency, driven by rising petrol prices and growing environmental concerns. Doctor Anjali Sharma, head of Automotive Research at I I T Madras, highlighted recent advancements in engine technology and lightweight materials contributing to improvements of up to fifteen percent in fuel economy across various car models.

unnormalised: However, challenges persist. "While engine efficiency has improved, driving habits in cities like Mumbai and Bangalore significantly impact real-world fuel consumption," Dr. Sharma noted. Stop-and-go traffic and aggressive driving can drastically reduce km/liter figures.
normalised: However, challenges persist. "While engine efficiency has improved, driving habits in cities like Mumbai and Bangalore significantly impact real-world fuel consumption," Doctor Sharma noted. Stop-and-go traffic and aggressive driving can drastically reduce kilometer per liter figures.

unnormalised: The Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI) is working on more stringent testing protocols to better reflect Indian driving conditions. They plan to introduce new standards requiring cars to demonstrate fuel efficiency under simulated city traffic scenarios.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the increased adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) offers a long-term solution, although concerns about charging infrastructure and battery costs (currently upwards of Rs. 2 Lakhs) remain.
